title: When recording a song does the entire band play at once, or is it patched together recording each musician separately? - Quora

response.answer_text: Depends on the band, the producer and the engineer. A lot of times the Beatles, Stones, Eagles and Doors did most of it all at once. Sometimes there are a few overdubs. Other bands may start with the basic tracks. When the song is complex it might be done in pieces. One ballad that I did we did the intro as one piece. The main song as basic tracks. The middle break as an overdubs acoustic track. We did all the vocals separately. A lot of bands do the Vocals and Lead solos as over dubs. You have to remember that up until 1960 there were only 2 track recorders and they would bounce track from one machine to another (Buddy Holly and Les Paul). From 1960 to 1967 there were only 4 track machines. The Beatles would record all the basic tracks on 1 track, the vocals and solos on the other 3 track. Sometimes they’d bounce from one 4 track to another 4 track. Starting in 1968 they had 8 track machines and by the early 1970s 16 track machines. These allowed them to put drums on two or three tracks and the rest of the band on the remaining tracks. They still often did vocals separately. By 1980 there were 24 track machines everywhere. Some 16 track machines could be retrofitted with 8 more preamps and a new head stack. Most 24 track machines could be outfitted with 16 track head stacks (wider individual track recording area). Now with ProTools major studios can have 128 tracks of audio (or more) and 256 or 512 tracks of MIDI, of course most studios are only equipped to record 24 to 32 track at one time, because they kept their old boards and have to buy preamp cards in 4 and 8 track configurations at a very expensive price and daisy chain these together. For the song Dreams by Fleetwood Mac the first tracks were drums, bass and scratch vocals. They ended up using 80% of the scratch vocals because her performance shined. About 20% were overdubed. So were keyboards and guitars. The lead guitar was recorded using several sources. Through a Leslie, through an amp, and other ways. They lost high end on the original master tapes so for some cuts they used two machines and ran the protection copy (a 2nd generation analog master) and the original together and kept them in sync by hand listening to the drum hits. With a Allman Brothers session, Dickie Betts played his solo as an overdub and their producer had him redo it several times because he heard better versions in rehearsal and live sessions. All recordings made before 1955 were mono. All recordings made before 1948 were direct to laquer disk. These were done with careful microphone placement and an engineer who turned knobs by hand and listened to what was being played. The vocals and music were done at once. Some Jazz records in the 1970s and even into the 1980s were done direct to Lacquer. Why? Tape does funny things to the sound of a piano that lacquer disks don’t do! Also tape has hiss. The Grateful Dead spliced 16 and 24 track tapes together to make some of their songs on the early albums. I knew one artist and the studio he went to would “plug” a 24 track tape with a spliced section on just a few tracks (not sure why anyone would do that). I saw the tape. There’d be a few inches long and wide with white spicing tape on the shiny side of the 2″ 24 track. The used a razor blade to cut out the section. I’d just mute the track.

It depends on the band. Some do it one way and some do it another. Ringo for instance perfers the whole band to play and they don’t use amps, they plug in direct to the board. And old Beatles trick. Paul on the other hand is apt to go in and lay down a piano or guitar with a guide vocal. Then the other musicians come in and lay their parts down. Drummer usually by himself. Final vocals usually go on last. I know some band members had home studios and will do a rough demo. But the demo. Usually of guitar or piano and a guide vocal. Brings that into the studio and the band members add to it.

It can be done LIVE with everyone there, but instruments will need to be separated so they don’t bleed into each other. You can also do individual tracking. I’d say a combination of both will open up endless possibilities. I’m finding lately to get basic tracks with guitar, bass, drums, and a scratch vocal. At that point, you can overdub and punch in parts until you’re satisfied. One last point, if you’re sequencing keyboard parts, you’ll need to record with a metronome, commonly referred to as a click track. It’s must harder to do it this way, but the timing will help everyone synchronize. I recorded a project in 2008—over 40 songs. I had to play every one with a click track. It was brutal, but it did improve my timing tremendously. It also forced me to take risks, which helped my chops develop, especially my double bass drumming. Cheers, Evan J. www.evanj31drum.com

My dad’s friend Stan White liked Duke Ellington because he asked Stan to just set up a mic, and they would work to get it right, and once it was, he could sit back and let the tape roll till the end of the session (one of the worst things that can happen is to make a great rendition of a song and find you didn’t ask the man to turn the machine on!) Others, he said, were fussier; but in general it was much simpler. However, a studio recording may more typically have either each member in a separate room, each wearing a headset (so you can have absolute integrity of each instrument track, so you can edit more easily), or have the whole band play together - so they will play more musically - but have mics attached to instruments or very focused so you can still have multi-tracks (again, to satisfy this fussy generation’s mania for perfection, and edit out the slightest error, improve a weak tone, etc.). And there may be many more methods - each studio has its own concept of how to do it, and develops its reputation thereby.

For our last album, “Elixir, The Soulgrass Sessions” Paula Boggs Band recorded mostly together as a band. Though the drummer, percussionist and I as lead singer/guitarist were in respective isolation booths, the entire 6 piece band could see each other. We overdubbed background vocals, there’s one song where the percussionist is playing 5 different instruments — something we can’t replicate playing live, we used a guest vocalist/choir for one song, and 4 songs included an overdubbed guest mandolin player. It was important for us to sound as “authentic” as possible while recording. It’s part of our brand.

See below for good answers. It depend on the sound you want. Examples, the great Chess records were made wit one or two mics, so were the early Motown cuts. The most recent Stones bues record was done with overheads, no close mic-ing. Listen to the mergers of the sounds, it creates a beautiful unified mix. Now listen to Justin Timberlake or Lady Bea. Major studio productions. These are meticulously mic-ed and edited. The separation of vocals and instruments is wonderfully clean, it’s a treat to geek-out on for music people. Which do you want? Neither is good onr bad.

This varies. Most studio (obviously live recordings don't count here) albums are a hodgepodge of engineering, overdubbing and suchlike. The last few Beatles studio albums had tracks on them where none of the band members heard were in each other's presence when recorded. Some performers are virtually single-person bands all by themselves, playing many parts and then laying down the pieces into a whole. In the last half a century or so, technology has made the making of music something that the classical composers of yesteryear would not have believed possible.

Victim of Love by the Eagles was recorded live in studio: Victim Of Love by Eagles Songfacts From LA Weekly: Fact or Myth? 5 Things You Might Not Know About Hotel California "V.O.L. Is Five-Piece Live"When you are a band as meticulous in the studio as the Eagles were under the auspices of their producer and engineer Bill Szymczyk, there are going to be some doubters as to whether or not you could play live. If you listen to the Forum performances on this expanded edition of Hotel California, or ever saw the group in concert back in the day, you already know the Eagles were one of the best live acts of the 1970s. But the band wanted to drive home the point that for all their fussy string arrangements and elaborate grooves, they were perfectly capable of playing live to tape — and when they cut the guitar-heavy side-two highlight "Victim of Love" that way, Szymczyk decided to commemorate the occasion.

Bands do it both ways. It’s typically more common for bands and artists to record parts separately because it’s cheaper, easier to record (DIY oftentimes), easier to edit, and sometimes all you need is a laptop and minimal recording gear. Bands that play together for a recording require a much bigger recording space, more recording gear, and the technical know-how to do it. This is usually done in bigger, professional studios which of course costs more and requires engineers to operate the gear.

Yes. It depends entirely on how that band, studio, and producer chooses to record. Both methods are employed and sometimes blended. Typically each band member will record individually. If you want a “live sound”, you have the band record a scratch track all together, then go back and rerecord each track separately to try to keep that live energy.

All the answers below are good and accurate but my favorite example of how extreme it can be is the Eagles “ Lyin'Eyes “ Each and every syllable of the opening line is spliced from a different take, I think it's 19 takes for 19 syllables. Beautiful vocal, though, maybe worth it.
Recording an entire band is called live recording. When it is patched together, it is called multi-track recording. It depends on which song you're talking about but both have their pros and cons.
I assume that it can be done both ways, especially with audio technology today and the possibility of multiple layered music
There are no rules. You do it however it takes to get it done.
